questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the green muscles marked? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in green is the lateral pterygoid muscle, and its primary function among the given options is depression of the mandible (opening the mouth). "Depression is brought about mainly by the lateral pterygoid" and it is "indispensible for actively opening the mouth."

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  • Depression of the mandible (primary active opener of the mouth)
  • Protrusion of the mandible
  • When one side contracts, it turns the chin to the opposite side

 

While the digastric, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles assist in depression, they primarily help when the mouth is opened wide or against resistance. The lateral pterygoid is the main muscle responsible for actively opening the mouth during normal function.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protrusion:

 

  • Protrusion refers to the forward movement of the lower jaw (mandible).
  • The lateral along with medial pterygoid muscle are responsible for protruding the mandible. When this muscle contracts on both sides, it causes the jaw to move forward.

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Elevation refers to the upward movement of the mandible, closing the mouth.
  • The primary muscles responsible for jaw elevation are the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid's main function is not jaw elevation but rather protrusion.

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Retraction refers to the backward movement of the mandible.
  • The primary muscles involved in jaw retraction are the temporalis and the posterior fibers of the digastric muscle. The lateral pterygoid is not primarily responsible for this movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetric clinic with signs of preterm labor. The medical team decides to administer corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Choose the correct option that should be used for fetal lung maturation: (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

For promoting fetal lung maturation in cases of threatened preterm labor, corticosteroids are administered to enhance the production of surfactant, which helps in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

 

The commonly recommended regimens are:

 

  • Betamethasone: 12 mg intramuscularly every 24 hours for 2 doses.
  • Dexamethasone: 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for 4 doses.

 

Given these recommendations, the correct options is:

 

B. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deferoxamine

 

Iron overdose, particularly with ferrous sulfate tablets, can lead to severe toxicity. Ingesting more than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron is considered potentially lethal. Acute iron poisoning presents with gastrointestinal symptoms initially and can progress to metabolic acidosis, shock, and multi-organ failure.

 

The presence of acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis is an important indicator of severe iron toxicity and an indication for the administration of an antidote. The appropriate antidote for acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine. Deferoxamine chelates free iron, forming a water-soluble complex that is excreted in the urine, thereby reducing iron's toxic effects on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is not effective in cases of iron poisoning. It does not adsorb metals like iron and can be harmful in certain situations like heavy metal poisoning, alcohols, petroleum products, and caustic substances.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Dimercaprol is used for chelation therapy in heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, mercury, gold) but is not effective for iron poisoning.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is another chelating agent, typically used for conditions such as Wilson's disease (copper overload) and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective in treating iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute iron intoxication with signs of toxicity such as acidosis, the antidote of choice is deferoxamine. Activated charcoal is not effective in iron poisoning and should not be used.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tool used in gene editing: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CRISPR

 

The core technologies now most commonly used to facilitate genome editing are -

 

1. Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) – CRISPs are guide RNAS. By delivering the Cas9 nuclease complexed with a synthetic guide RNA (gRNA) into a cell, the cell's genome can be cut at a desired location, allowing existing genes to be removed and/or new ones added in vivo.

 

 

2. Transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs)

 

3. Zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs)

 

4. Homing endonucleases or meganucleases.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Big data: Refers to the large volume of data that can be analyzed to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions, but it is not a tool for gene editing.

 

Option C. Gene Xpert: Is a diagnostic tool used to detect genetic material from specific pathogens (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and is not related to gene editing.

 

Option D. GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies): Involves scanning genomes from many different people to find genetic markers associated with specific diseases. While related to genetics, it is not a tool for directly editing genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR is a powerful gene editing tool that enables precise modifications of the genome and is used extensively in genetic research and therapeutic applications.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

 

Leptin is a peptide hormone released from adipocytes

 

Leptin plays an important role in controlling the adipose tissue and food intake.

 

Actions of leptin:

 

  • Acts on hypothalamus and inhibits the feeding center, resulting in stoppage of food intake
  • Stimulates the metabolic reactions involved in utilization of fat stored in adipose tissue for energy. Thus, the circulating leptin level informs the brain about the energy storage and the necessity to regulate metabolic reactions, food intake and body weight
  • Elevated leptin levels might have a permissive effect on the pubertal process and pubertal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH: Incorrect as GnRH directly stimulates the secretion of LH and FSH, which are critical for puberty but not considered permissive.

 

Option C. Insulin: While it plays a supportive role in general growth and development, it is not specifically permissive for the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. GH: Growth hormone is vital for growth and development during puberty but does not have a direct permissive role in the initiation of puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty, indicating to the hypothalamus that sufficient energy reserves are available for the safe progression of reproductive development. This hormone essentially "permits" the initiation of puberty when energy conditions are met.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth. (BNS 229)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (up to 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 7 years. (BNS 238)

choices.text: Mesangial cell proliferation
Loss of foot processes

questions.text: The most consistent histological feature in cases of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis (RPGN). (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Crescent formation

 

Explanation:

 

The hallmark feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is the formation of crescents in the glomeruli. These crescents, composed of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and infiltrating leukocytes within the Bowman's capsule, signify severe glomerular injury. This morphological change is the primary indicator of RPGN, reflecting rapid and severe impairment of renal function. The presence of crescents typically indicates a dire prognosis, often correlating with swift progression to renal failure if not adequately treated.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option b. Mesangial cell proliferation is common in various glomerulonephritides but not a definitive feature of RPGN.

 

Option c. IgA deposition characterizes IgA nephropathy, which may progress but not typically as rapidly as crescentic RPGN.

 

Option d. Loss of foot processes is seen in minimal change disease and other causes of nephrotic syndrome, rather than primarily in RPGN.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Crescent formation in the glomeruli is the distinguishing and most consistent feature in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, indicating severe and swift progression of renal damage.

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.

 

Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. late decelerations are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.

 

Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can mimic erythroblastosis fetalis due to its ability to infect erythroid progenitor cells and inhibit erythropoiesis, leading to severe anemia. Erythroblastosis fetalis typically results from maternal antibodies targeting fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis and severe anemia; Parvovirus B19 causes a similar effect through a direct infection of the erythroid cells.

 

Parvovirus B19 is associated with:

 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Transient aplastic crisis
  3. Pure red cell aplasia
  4. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)

 

Erythema infectiosum rash :

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): Incorrect, as HSV does not typically cause the hematologic manifestations associated with erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Incorrect, while EBV can cause hematological disturbances, it does not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis but is more associated with conditions like infectious mononucleosis.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: Incorrect, this group of viruses, which includes enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, does not produce hematological symptoms that mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Glucosamine and chondroitin sulphate are used in the treatment of arthritis which is a degenerative joint disease.

 

Glucosamines are amino sugars. Mucopolysaccharides or glycosamino glycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides, containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Examples of mucopolysaccharides are hyaluronic acid, heparin, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate and keratan sulfate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin, not treated with glucosamines.

 

Option C. Alzheimer's disease: This neurodegenerative condition involves the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Glucosamines are not used in its treatment.

 

Option D. Cancer: Cancer treatment involves a wide range of therapies such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Glucosamines are not used in cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucosamine is used in the treatment of arthritis due to its role in maintaining healthy cartilage and joint function.

choices.text: IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, and MRI
IV fluids, MRI, assisted drainage, and laparotomy
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, MRI, and laparotomy

questions.text: Which of the following steps are included in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis in a patient with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage

 

MRI is not indicated in patients with acute necrotising pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct steps in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis include IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage. Large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis are complications of acute pancreatitis that require immediate management.

 

Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and early nutrition are initiated, followed by contrast-enhanced computed tomography to diagnose necrosis. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration is done, and the aspirate is subjected to Gram staining and culture sensitivity. IV antibiotics are started with carbapenem as the first-choice drug.

 

The step-up approach, which includes percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement, is adopted for definitive management. Hence, the correct option is C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue. His symptoms began after a recent viral illness. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, mild pedal edema, and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and echocardiography reveals mild left ventricular dysfunction. The patient is suspected of having myocarditis. What is the most accurate diagnostic test for confirming myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. Endomyocardial biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard diagnostic test for myocarditis, providing direct histological evidence of myocardial inflammation. It allows for the identification of inflammatory cell infiltrates, myocyte degeneration, and necrosis, which are characteristic findings of active myocarditis. This procedure is critical in distinguishing myocarditis from other conditions that cause similar symptoms and can help determine the underlying etiology, guiding appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac CT:


Cardiac CT is primarily used to assess coronary anatomy and is not typically used to diagnose myocarditis. While it can show structural abnormalities and rule out coronary artery disease, it lacks the capability to detect myocardial inflammation, making it unsuitable for confirming myocarditis.

 

Option B. Viral serology:


Viral serology can detect antibodies against specific viral pathogens that may cause myocarditis; however, it does not confirm the presence of myocarditis in the heart tissue. Serological testing is not specific or sensitive enough to diagnose myocarditis, as many individuals may have positive antibodies without active myocardial inflammation.

 

Option D. Autoantibody testing:


Autoantibody testing can be helpful in diagnosing autoimmune conditions that may lead to myocarditis, such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis. However, it does not provide a direct assessment of myocardial inflammation or damage, making it an indirect and non-specific method for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endomyocardial biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test for myocarditis, allowing direct histological examination of myocardial tissue to confirm inflammation and differentiate between various etiologies. Non-invasive tests like cardiac CT, viral serology, and autoantibody testing are not specific enough for diagnosis, highlighting the importance of biopsy in cases where accurate identification of myocardial inflammation is necessary.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

choices.text: Start ART if CD4 <200
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ATT and ART simultaneously

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks


In HIV patients with tuberculosis (TB), it is crucial to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first to reduce the mycobacterial load before initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART). This approach helps to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a life-threatening condition due to massive cytokine response triggered by a rapid increase in CD4 count., which can occur if ART is started too early. The general recommendation is to start ART by 2 weeks -2 months, after ATT initiation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Starting ART only if CD4 <200: does not address the immediate need for TB treatment.

 

Option B. Starting ART before ATT: can lead to IRIS.

 

Option D. Starting both therapies simultaneously:  increases the risk of IRIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with TB, start ATT first and then initiate ART after 2 weeks-2 months duration.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: ALK positivity is seen in which of the following neoplasms: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor

 

ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) is seen in Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of lung.

 

(ALK) Anaplastic lymphoma kinase {CD246} is a tyrosine kinase receptor encoded by the ALK gene located on chromosome 2p

 

ALK positive tumors respond to ALK kinase inhibitors, therefore it has an excellent prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibromatosis: ALK positivity is not associated with fibromatosis. This condition is characterized by fibroblastic proliferation, and ALK is not typically involved.

 

Option B. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma does not show ALK positivity. It is more often associated with specific translocations, such as t(X;18)(p11;q11), resulting in SS18-SSX fusion genes.

 

Option C. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is characterized by a specific EWSR1-FLI1 fusion gene due to a translocation involving chromosomes 11 and 22. ALK positivity is not seen in Ewing sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALK positivity is seen in:

 

  • Lung Cancers – Adenocarcinoma, small cell cancer, anaplastic cancer
  • Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Renal cell carcinomas
  • Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
  • Breast cancer notably the inflammatory subtype
  • Colonic adenocarcinoma
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
  • Anaplastic thyroid cancer

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

 

SUICIDE INHIBTION

 

Suicide inhibition, also known as mechanism-based inhibition, is a unique and fascinating aspect of enzyme kinetics. It's a process where an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue, which initially seems like a normal substrate to the enzyme. However, as the enzyme starts to act on this 'pseudo-substrate,' a chemical reaction occurs that modifies the enzyme in such a way that it becomes irreversibly inactivated. This process is termed 'suicide' because the enzyme actively participates in its own inhibition.

 

STEPS INVOLVED IN SUICIDE INHIBITION

 

  1. Binding: The suicide substrate, which is often structurally similar to the actual substrate, binds to the enzyme's active site.
  2. Initial Reaction: The enzyme catalyses a reaction on this substrate analogue, similar to how it would act on its natural substrate.
  3. Formation of Reactive Intermediate: This reaction, however, leads to the formation of a chemically reactive intermediate. This intermediate is the key to the suicide inhibition mechanism.
  4. Modification of Enzyme: The reactive intermediate then reacts with the enzyme itself, leading to a covalent modification of the enzyme. This modification typically occurs at the active site, crucial for the enzyme's activity.
  5. Irreversible Inhibition: As a result of this modification, the enzyme is irreversibly inactivated. It can no longer bind to its natural substrate or catalyse the reaction it was designed for.
  6. Specificity: One of the key features of suicide inhibition is its specificity. Because the inhibitor is structurally similar to the natural substrate, the process is highly specific to the targeted enzyme. This makes suicide inhibitors very effective as drugs, as they can selectively target and inactivate specific enzymes in the body.

 

Other Options:

Option B. The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible: This is true. The substrate analogue binds irreversibly to the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Option C. They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design: This is true. Suicide inhibitors are designed to be highly specific for the target enzyme, making them valuable in rational drug design.

 

Option D. The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it: This is true. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of the substrate analogue to a reactive intermediate, which then irreversibly modifies the enzyme, leading to its inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLINICAL IMPORTANCE

 

Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.

 

Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

 

EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS

 

  • Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • Aspirin
  • Allopurinol
  • MAO inhibitors

choices.text: Cat scratch disease

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with high fever, cough, and a widespread rash that started on his face and spread to his body over the past three days. He also has conjunctivitis and runny nose. His parents report that he has not received his vaccinations. On physical examination, he appears ill with generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is performed, and the histological examination reveals multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. These cells are indicated by arrows in the image. Based on these histological findings, which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Measles

 

Explanation:

 

The histological image shows Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells, which are multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, characteristic of measles. These cells are pathognomonic for measles and can be found in lymphoid tissues, the lung, and sputum. They often appear within enlarged germinal centers and are associated with marked follicular hyperplasia. Warthin-Finkeldey cells are specific to measles and are not typically seen in other common viral infections, helping to differentiate measles from other conditions with similar clinical presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella


Rubella can cause lymphadenopathy and a rash similar to measles, but it does not produce Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells. Rubella primarily affects the skin and lymph nodes but lacks the characteristic multinucleated giant cells with inclusions seen in measles.

 

Option C. Cat scratch disease


Cat scratch disease, caused by Bartonella henselae, presents with regional lymphadenopathy and suppurative inflammation. The histological hallmark is granulomatous inflammation with stellate necrosis, but it does not feature Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

 

Option D. Langerhans cell histiocytosis


Langerhans cell histiocytosis is characterized by clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, and histologically it shows large cells with grooved nuclei and abundant eosinophils. It does not present with the multinucleated Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells seen in measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic for measles, presenting as multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic inclusions that can be seen in lymph nodes, lung tissue, and sputum. Identifying these cells in histological samples is critical for diagnosing measles, especially in patients with classic clinical features and a history of incomplete vaccination

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations
It is an anti-craving drug for alcohol
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists maximum up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body due to its inhibition of the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. This leads to a range of unpleasant symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, which are part of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. This reaction is intentional and serves as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It is given at a dose of 250mg/day, dose may be increased up to 500 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disulfiram is not primarily an anti-craving drug for alcohol. It works by creating an aversive reaction to alcohol rather than reducing the craving for alcohol. Medications like naltrexone or acamprosate are more accurately described as anti-craving drugs.

 

Option C. Disulfiram should be prescribed to highly motivated individuals. It requires a commitment to abstain from alcohol due to the serious nature of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. It is not typically recommended for individuals who are minimally motivated or likely to continue consuming alcohol.

 

Option D. The action of Disulfiram can persist beyond 2-3 days after stopping the drug. Its inhibitory effect on acetaldehyde dehydrogenase can last for up to a week or more in some cases, making it possible for the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction to occur even several days after the last dose of Disulfiram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes a severe and unpleasant reaction due to the accumulation of acetaldehyde, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, serving as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It should be used in highly motivated individuals committed to abstaining from alcohol.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fever, neck pain, and vomiting. He subsequently died, and the brain's appearance at autopsy, along with the micrograph shown below, suggests a specific pathogen. What is the most likely pathogen  involved? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Cryptococcus

 

Explanation:
 

The diagnosis is supported by the clinical presentation of meningoencephalitis and the distinctive "soap bubble" lesions observed in the brain parenchyma, a hallmark of Cryptococcus infection in HIV-infected patients. Cryptococcus, a yeast with a thick gelatinous capsule, is known for its CNS involvement, particularly in immunocompromised hosts. This organism can expand perivascular spaces in the gray matter without significant inflammatory response, especially in those with weakened immune systems, such as HIV/AIDS patients. These expansions, termed "soap bubble" lesions, are pathognomonic for cryptococcal infection.

 

Other options:
 

Option A. Toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the CNS, which differ from the "soap bubble" appearance.
 

Option B. Echinococcus multilocularis causes cystic lesions in organs like the liver and lungs, not typically presenting with "soap bubble" lesions in the brain.
 

Option C. Herpes meningitis is more likely to cause a diffuse meningeal inflammation rather than the distinct lesions seen with Cryptococcus.

 

Educational Objectives:
 

Cryptococcus is known for producing "soap bubble" lesions in the CNS, a distinctive feature crucial for diagnosing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis in HIV-positive patients.

questions.text: The fluorescent in situ hybridization cannot be useful for detection of which of the following genetic defects?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point mutation

 

Point mutation: Point mutations involve a change in a single nucleotide base pair, which FISH cannot detect because it is designed to detect larger structural changes. For detecting point mutations, more sensitive techniques like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and specific variants such as single base primer extension assays are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes binding parts of the chromosome to detect and localize the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences. It is particularly useful for identifying genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations by visualizing the chromosomal location of the gene of interest.

 

Option A. Deletion: FISH can detect deletions by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the probe should bind.

 

Option C. Amplification: FISH can detect gene amplifications by showing multiple fluorescent signals in the region of interest.

 

Option D: Translocation: FISH can detect translocations by showing split signals in different parts of the chromosome or in different chromosomes, indicating that parts of the chromosome have been rearranged.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations but is effective for identifying larger genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations.

choices.text: Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).

 

Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be forcefully expired after forceful inspiration


            = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + Expiratory reserve volume
 

 

Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV

 

Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration: Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

 

Option B. Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration: Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.

 

Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: Incorrect, this combination describes the inspiratory capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45%

 

To calculate the percentage of burns, the "Rule of Nines" is commonly used in medicine. According to this rule, each area of the body is assigned a percentage value.

 

For example, the head and neck are typically assigned 9%, each upper limb is assigned 9% (18% total for both), and the front and back of the chest are assigned 18%. When we add these percentages together, we get a total of 45% burns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace's rule of nine.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Burns on the head & neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

 

Wallace's rule of nine:

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Myxoid liposarcoma
Spindle lipoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoid liposarcoma

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

The image shows a lot of ground substance, as well as some branching capillaries and immature adipocytes.

 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults, typically appearing in the fifth to sixth decade of life.

 

They are most commonly found in the proximal extremities (deep soft tissues) and the retroperitoneum.

 

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into four subtypes: 

 

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: resembles lipoma but contains uni- or multi-vacuolated lipoblasts. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-g15.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: Most common histologic type. It is composed of monomorphic, fusiform or stellate cells representing primitive mesenchymal cells, lying dispersed in mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance. Occasional tumor giant cells may be present. Prominent meshwork of capillaries forming chicken-wire patterns is a conspicuous feature. It is associated with t (12;16).
  • Round cell liposarcoma is composed of uniform, round to oval cells having fine multi vacuolated cytoplasm with central hyperchromatic nuclei. Round cell liposarcoma may resemble a signet-ring carcinoma but mucin stains help in distinguishing the two.
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: highly undifferentiated and the most anaplastic type. There are numerous large tumor giant cells and bizarre lipoblasts. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoma: This is incorrect. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue and do not show the histological features or molecular translocation (t (12;16)) seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option C. Spindle lipoma: This is incorrect. Spindle cell lipomas are benign tumors composed of spindle-shaped cells mixed with mature adipocytes and do not have the mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance or the t (12;16) translocation seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option D. Polymorphic lipoma: This is incorrect. Polymorphic lipomas are also benign and do not exhibit the characteristic histological features or molecular markers of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxoid liposarcoma is the most common histologic type of liposarcoma, characterized by a mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance, a prominent capillary network forming chicken-wire patterns, and the presence of the translocation t (12;16).

choices.text: Labile hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension
Treatment of resistant migraine
Resistant Parkinson's disease

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for treatment of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide (NO) has specific clinical applications, particularly in the field of pulmonary medicine. It is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, especially in certain acute settings. It works by selectively dilating the pulmonary vessels by increasing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), thereby reducing pulmonary artery pressure and improving oxygenation. Inhaled nitric oxide is particularly noted for its use in newborns with hypoxic respiratory failure associated with pulmonary hypertension. It can also be used in the acute management of pulmonary hypertension in adults during cardiac surgery or critical care settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labile Hypertension: Inhaled nitric oxide is not used for the treatment of labile hypertension. Hypertension is typically managed with systemic medications rather than inhaled agents.

 

Option C. Treatment of Resistant Migraine: Inhaled nitric oxide is not a standard treatment for migraines, whether typical or resistant. Migraine treatment usually involves a range of other pharmacological interventions.

 

Option D. Resistant Parkinson's Disease: There is no established role for inhaled nitric oxide in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson's disease management primarily involves medications that affect dopamine pathways.

 

Other uses of inhaled Nitric Oxide:

 

  • Neonatal Care: It is particularly valuable in the treatment of newborns with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) to improve oxygenation.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): While its benefits in ARDS in adults are still a subject of research and debate, it has been used for its pulmonary vasodilator effects in some critical care settings.
  • Cardiac Surgery: Inhaled NO can be used during cardiac surgery to control pulmonary artery pressures.
  • Lung Transplantation: It may be used to reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve graft function immediately after transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in acute settings to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve oxygenation. It is not used for labile hypertension, migraines, or Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

choices.text: Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

 

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

 

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages
  • Abundant cytoplasm
  • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis: While mitral stenosis can result from calcification, it is more typically associated with chronic rheumatic heart disease, which involves Aschoff bodies rather than calcification alone.

 

Option C. Granuloma; Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, but it does not present with Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Non-caseating granuloma: Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not Aschoff bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1044

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of persistent lower back pain and difficulty walking, which have progressively worsened over the last six months. He has no history of recent trauma or significant injury. On examination, he has tenderness over the lumbar spine and limited range of motion due to pain. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. A bone scan reveals multiple areas of increased uptake in the spine and pelvis, and X-rays show dense, sclerotic lesions in these areas. Based on these imaging findings, which condition is most commonly associated with predominantly osteoblastic metastases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Prostate cancer

 

Explanation

 

Breakdown of the Case:

 

  • Elderly male (70 years old)
  • Persistent lower back pain and difficulty walking – suggests spinal pathology
  • No trauma – rules out mechanical cause
  • Localized spinal tenderness and reduced mobility – possible vertebral pathology
  • Elevated ALP – marker of increased bone turnover (often seen in bone metastases)
  • Bone scan – shows increased uptake in spine and pelvis (common sites for prostate mets)
  • X-rays show dense, sclerotic lesions – hallmark of osteoblastic metastases

 

Predominantly osteoblastic metastases, characterized by sclerotic or dense bone lesions, are most commonly seen in prostate cancer. Prostate cancer is known for metastasizing to the bone, where it induces osteoblastic activity, leading to increased bone formation and sclerotic changes visible on imaging. While other cancers such as small cell lung cancer, carcinoid tumors, and Hodgkin lymphoma can also cause osteoblastic metastases, prostate cancer is the classic and most frequently associated malignancy with this pattern of bone involvement.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Small cell lung cancer: Small cell lung cancer can occasionally produce osteoblastic metastases, but it is much less common compared to prostate cancer. Osteoblastic lesions in small cell lung cancer are relatively rare and usually mixed with osteolytic lesions.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors can cause osteoblastic metastases, but these are relatively uncommon. They usually present with other systemic symptoms related to hormone production rather than extensive sclerotic bone lesions.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma can cause sclerotic bone metastases, particularly in advanced stages. However, this is less common compared to the classic osteoblastic metastases seen in prostate cancer, making Hodgkin lymphoma a less likely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoblastic metastases, which appear as dense, sclerotic lesions on imaging, are most commonly associated with prostate cancer due to its propensity to promote new bone formation at metastatic sites.

choices.text: 1-d, 2- c, 3- b, 4-a
1-c, 2- a, 3- d, 4- b
1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d

questions.text: Match the following stains with their respective tissue: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c

 

The correct match is 1- a, 2- b, 3- d, 4-c.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Prussian blue (a): This stain is used to detect iron in tissue samples, specifically hemosiderin, a storage form of iron.
  • PAS (b): The Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used to highlight glycogen and other carbohydrates in tissues. It is commonly used in diagnosing certain storage diseases and fungal infections.
  • Congo red (c): Congo red is a special stain used to detect amyloid, a protein that can abnormally accumulate in tissues, leading to conditions such as amyloidosis. Under polarized light, amyloid stained with Congo red shows apple-green birefringence.
  • Fite Faraco stain (d): This stain is used to detect leprosy bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae) in tissue samples. It is a modification of the acid-fast stain and is specifically tailored to highlight these bacteria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, with a smoking history of 20 pack years, presented in OPD with breathlessness and chest pain. Further investigations revealed a lung tumor. On staining, cells are positive for chromogranin. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small cell carcinoma 

 

History of chronic smoking and lung tumor cells staining positive for chromogranin suggests small cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

SMALL CELL CARCINOMAS:

 

  1. This highly malignant tumor has a distinctive cell type.
  2. Strongly associated with cigarette smoking
  3. This lung cancer type is most commonly associated with ectopic hormone production
  4. Electron microscopy shows
    • Dense-core neurosecretory granules are present along the bronchial epithelium which can secrete polypeptide hormones
    • Presence of neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD57 (in 75% of cases) and parathormone-like and other hormonally active products suggest derivation of this tumor from neuroendocrine progenitor cells of the lining bronchial epithelium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenocarcinoma: This is the most common subtype of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers, and it typically involves peripheral lung lesions. It is characterized by markers like TTF-1, NAPSIN-A, and CEA, rather than chromogranin.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type is also associated with smoking but is more likely to present centrally in the lungs. It shows keratinization and intercellular bridges on histology and is associated with markers like p40 and p63, not chromogranin.

 

Option C. Large cell carcinoma: This diagnosis is typically a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have a specific marker like chromogranin. It is also more common in non-smokers and presents as a peripheral tumor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Herpes-simplex virus

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

 

Infection with the Herpes simplex virus (HS) causes punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

 

Immunocompromised patients are more likely to develop HS esophagitis.

 

Endoscopic findings may include multiple discrete or coalescent small ulcers that appear superficial, punched out, or volcano-like.

 

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are seen here:

 

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Infected squamous epithelial cells show 3 M’s:
    • Molding of nuclear contours
    • Margination of chromatin to the periphery of nuclei
    • Multinucleation
  • Intranuclear inclusions:
    • Cowdry type A: acidophilic inclusion with surrounding clear halo
    • Equivocal cases require an HSV immunohistochemical (IHC) stain to confirm the diagnosis

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Causes larger, shallow ulcers and might involve deeper tissue layers, with "owl's eye" inclusions typically seen.

 

Option C. Candida: Presents typically as white plaques or linear fissures rather than punched-out ulcers.

 

Option D. Acid: Causes erosive esophagitis with continuous areas of inflammation rather than discrete ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

 

Genomic Imprinting is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents.

 

Important functional differences exist between the paternal allele and the maternal allele. These differences result from an epigenetic process, called imprinting. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

 

Genomic imprinting is a process of silencing genes through DNA methylation. The repressed allele is methylated, while the active allele is unmethylated.

 

E.g., Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Both of these syndromes can be caused by imprinting or other errors involving genes on the long arm of chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal mosaicism: Gonadal mosaicism refers to the presence of more than one genetically distinct cell line within the gonads. This can lead to different genetic outcomes in offspring but does not involve the differential effect of the same gene based on parental origin. Therefore, it is not related to genomic imprinting.

 

Option C. Anticipation: Anticipation is a phenomenon where a genetic disorder appears earlier and with increased severity in successive generations. This is different from genomic imprinting, as it does not involve the differential effects of a gene based on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father.

 

Option D. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance occurs when not all individuals carrying a disease-causing mutation exhibit the disease phenotype. This concept is unrelated to the differential effect of a gene based on its parental origin and does not describe genomic imprinting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 328

choices.text: They can differentiate
They can replicate
They can divide without any regulatory stimulus
They can regenerate damaged tissues

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about stem cells? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus.

 

Stem cells are characterized by their self-renewal properties and by their capacity to generate differentiated cell lineages. Stem cells give rise to all the various differentiated tissues. In adults, stem cells replace damaged cells and maintain tissue populations.

 

The properties of stem cells are:

 

  1. Obligatory asymmetric replication, in which with each stem cell division, one of the daughter cells retains its self-renewing capacity while the other enters a differentiation pathway
  2. Stochastic differentiation, in which a stem cell population is maintained by the balance between stem cell divisions that generate either two self-renewing stem cells or two cells that will differentiate.

 

The types of stem cells are:

 

  • Embryonic stem cells which are totipotent
  • Adult stem cells present in stem cell niches

 

The pluripotency of stem cells is due to factors like:

 

  • Oct3/4
  • Kif 4
  • Sox 2
  • c-myc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They can differentiate: This is true. Stem cells have the ability to differentiate into various specialized cell types.

 

Option B. They can replicate: This is true. Stem cells can self-renew, meaning they can replicate themselves to maintain the stem cell pool.

 

Option D. They can regenerate damaged tissues: This is true. Stem cells can help regenerate damaged tissues by differentiating into the necessary cell types to replace lost or damaged cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stem cells do not divide without any regulatory stimulus; their division and differentiation are tightly controlled to maintain tissue homeostasis and prevent uncontrolled growth.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 165-170

questions.text: Which of the following structure is affected in pancreas of a patient with Cystic Fibrosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The part labelled 'B' in the image is the acini (exocrine pancreas) which is affected in cystic fibrosis.

 

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, there is accumulation mucin in ducts of pancreas which leads to atrophy of exocrine pancreas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: Likely corresponds to a blood vessel, which is not primarily affected in CF.

 

Option C. C: Corresponds to a larger duct, which may also be obstructed by mucus, but the question specifically asks about the structure most commonly affected, which is the acini.

 

Option D. D: May correspond to an islet of Langerhans (endocrine pancreas), which is less commonly affected in the early stages of CF compared to the exocrine acini.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Cystic Fibrosis, the acini (exocrine pancreas) are primarily affected due to mucus accumulation in the ducts, leading to atrophy and fibrosis of the exocrine pancreas.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image (pink)? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The given electrophoresis picture shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma would typically present with a sharp, monoclonal spike in the gamma region (known as an M-spike or paraprotein spike) due to the overproduction of a single type of immunoglobulin by malignant plasma cells. This pattern is not seen in the provided electrophoresis image.

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is generally associated with a chronic inflammatory response and can show a polyclonal increase in the gamma region due to chronic immune activation. However, it does not show the specific hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Hepatic cirrhosis: In hepatic cirrhosis, the electrophoresis pattern often shows a polyclonal increase in the gamma region (polyclonal gammopathy), sometimes with a beta-gamma bridging pattern. This pattern is not consistent with the hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase observed in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The electrophoresis pattern showing hypoalbuminemia combined with an increase in alpha-2 globulin is most indicative of nephrotic syndrome, reflecting the characteristic loss of albumin and retention of larger plasma proteins in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL- 4

 

The cytokine not involved in TH1 response is IL-4.

 

T-cell response in this early stage is dominated by TH1 cells that produce IFN-γ, which stimulates macrophages to secrete high levels of the cytokines TNF, IL-1, and IL-6 that cause fever.

 

IL-12 is secreted by macrophages and promotes the proliferation of TH1 cells.

 

The 1 cells secrete IL-2 which activates natural killer cells (NK cells) and cytotoxic T cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma) is a key cytokine produced by Th1 cells. It activates macrophages and enhances their ability to destroy ingested microbes, and it also promotes the production of IgG antibodies that are essential for opsonization and phagocytosis of pathogens.

 

Option B. IL-2 (Interleukin-2): IL-2 (Interleukin-2) is produced by Th1 cells and plays a critical role in the activation and proliferation of T cells, including natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which are crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

Option C. IL-12 (Interleukin-12): IL-12 (Interleukin-12) is produced by antigen-presenting cells (like dendritic cells and macrophages) and is essential for the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells. It also stimulates the production of IFN-γ by these Th1 cells.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy

questions.text: Identify this condition? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic placenta, characterized by a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both a chorion and an amniotic sac. This type of twinning occurs when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation, after the formation of the trophoblast, leading to a monochorionic condition.

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestations have a high fetal death rate due to several complications:

 

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

 

The best time for delivery of monochorionic monoamniotic twins is between 32-34 weeks via Caesarean section.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome: This is a complication seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies. It involves a donor twin and a recipient twin. The donor twin is anemic, growth-restricted, and has oligohydramnios, while the recipient twin is polycythemic, has polyhydramnios, and suffers from circulatory overload.

 

Option B. Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In this type of pregnancy, there are two amniotic cavities and one chorion. This occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 4-7 days of gestation.

 

Option D. Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy: This pregnancy type involves two amniotic cavities and two chorions. It occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 0-3 days of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies involve a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane, occurring when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 233-234,

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough, weight loss, histology of the pathology is as shown below. What is the most likely cytokine involved? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • IFN-γ is crucial in the immune response against intracellular pathogens, including the activation of macrophages and the formation of granulomas, as seen in tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases. It is produced primarily by T-helper cells (Th1) and is critical for orchestrating the cellular immune response that results in the granuloma formation evident in the provided histology.

 

Other Options:
