Option B. Complement 5a protein: Involved in the inflammatory process, enhancing the immune response by attracting immune cells to sites of infection, but not directly involved in granuloma formation.

 

Option C. Histamine: A mediator in allergic reactions, involved in vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, not typically associated with chronic inflammatory or granulomatous responses.

 

Option D. Prostaglandin: These are lipid compounds that mediate inflammation. Like histamine, they are more often associated with immediate inflammatory responses and pain, rather than chronic inflammation or granuloma formation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Interferon gamma is key in managing intracellular infections and is responsible for the activation of macrophages and other immune cells that culminate in granuloma formation, a central feature in controlling persistent pathogens such as those seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

choices.text: Monitoring of lithium therapy
Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy
Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics
Administration of nicotine patches

questions.text: Z track technique is used for (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

 

Z track technique is a technique used for intramuscular injection.


During Z track technique, skin is stretched to one side before injecting the needle so that the point of injection and point of deposition of drug are not in straight line. This decreases the risk of efflux back of drug.

 

Advantages of Z track technique –

 

  • It will not cause any pigmentation
  • Lithium and carbamazepine are oral drugs and monitoring is done by taking blood through intravenous route.
  • Long acting depot antipsychotics are given by intramuscular route via z-track technique.
  • Nicotine patches are applied on the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is monitored through blood tests, not intramuscular injections. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure lithium levels.

 

Option B. Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy is also monitored through blood tests. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure carbamazepine levels, and the medication is usually taken orally.

 

Option D. Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are applied transdermally to the skin. The Z track technique is not relevant for this method of administration.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Z track technique is used for intramuscular injections, particularly for long-acting depot antipsychotics, to ensure proper deposition of the medication and prevent leakage back through the injection path.

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioblastoma

 

Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

 

Many childhood tumors have been collectively referred to as small round blue cell tumors due to their primitive histologic appearance.

 

The differential diagnosis of such tumors includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, medulloblastoma and retinoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a classic example of a small round blue cell tumor. It is a highly malignant tumor that primarily affects bone and soft tissues, particularly in children and young adults.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a small round blue cell tumor of the eye, commonly seen in children. It is characterized by the presence of small, undifferentiated cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another example of a small round blue cell tumor. It arises from neural crest cells and is most commonly found in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioblastoma is not classified as a small round blue cell tumor, unlike Ewing's sarcoma, retinoblastoma, and neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 882

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barrett’s esophagus

 

This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett's esophagus. Note the transition between esophageal squamous mucosa and Barrett metaplasia, with abundant metaplastic goblet cells.

 

 

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett's Esophagus require that periodic endoscopy with biopsy, for detection of dysplasia every 1-2 years to detect dysplasias.

 

The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagitis: While esophagitis, inflammation of the esophagus, may be seen in GERD, it does not show the characteristic intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells as seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer originates from the squamous cells of the esophagus and does not involve the metaplastic changes characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can develop from Barrett's esophagus, but the histological image provided is more consistent with the premalignant stage of Barrett's esophagus rather than adenocarcinoma itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition marked by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells within the esophageal squamous mucosa, requiring regular surveillance for dysplasia and potential progression to adenocarcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1464

questions.text: Which fixation technique is used for fat in the histopathological examination? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frozen section

 

Identification of neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues may require fresh smears or sometimes cryostat sections of tissue. 

 

Rapid freezing makes the tissue sample firmer and ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

 

Cryostat machine temperature ranges from 0°C to -35°C. Most of the tissue can be sectioned between -15°C to -25°C. Tissue samples with high water content can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues with high fat content are cut at a lower temperature.

 

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain.

 

It is used in the following conditions:

 

  • Fat emboli in lung tissue
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin
  • Lipid-rich carcinomas

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IHC (Immunohistochemistry): This technique is used for detecting specific proteins within tissue sections but is not specifically used for fat preservation or visualization.

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Liquid paraffin is most commonly used for the fixation technique in the histopathological examination. It involves the fixation of tissues using formalin and subsequent embedding in paraffin wax. This technique allows for long-term preservation of tissue morphology and cellular details, making it the standard preservation procedure.

 

Option D. Formalin fixed: Formalin fixation is the standard method for preserving general tissue morphology but is not ideal for fat preservation, as it can dissolve lipid content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic formalin is the most commonly used fixation technique for preserving and examining fat in histopathological sections.

 

Liquid paraffin is the most commonly used embedding agent.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania tropica

 

 

Difference between Leishmania tropica and donovani is that tropica do not invade organs. It causes cutaneous leishmaniasis otherwise called as Delhi boil, Aleppo boil.

 

Following image shows an ulcer surrounded by erythema

 

 

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

 

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

 

 

LIFE CYCLE IS GIVEN OF FILARIA:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia causes babesiosis, a tick-borne disease, presents as a malaria-like illness with fever, chills, and hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cause diseases like African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) and American trypanosomiasis (Chagas disease), presents with different clinical features, such as fever, swollen lymph nodes, and neurological symptoms in African trypanosomiasis while in Chagas disease, fever and swelling at the infection site, and cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Histoplasma (dimorphic fungus) causes histoplasmosis. Mostly affects the lungs and then can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised individuals. Presents variably, but it does not typically cause an ulcer with erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute lymphoblastic leukemia? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytokeratin

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma.

 

Immunophenotype in ALL –

 

  • Terminal deoxynucleotidyl-transferase (TdT), a specialized DNA polymerase, is positive in more than 95% of cases.
  • Lymphoblasts usually express the pan B-cell marker CD19 and the transcription factor PAX5, as well as CD10.
  • More mature “late pre-B” ALLs express CD10, CD19, CD20, and cytoplasmic IgM heavy chain (μ chain).
  • T-ALLs are arrested at various stages of pre-T cell development. In most cases the cells are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • “Late” pre-T cell tumors are positive CD3, CD4, and CD8

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TdT: A highly specific marker for ALL, present in over 95% of cases.

 

Option B. CD1a: Commonly expressed in T-ALL, particularly in early T-cell development stages.

 

Option C. CD3: A marker for T-cell lineage, used in identifying T-ALL and distinguishing it from B-cell lineage ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and is instead an epithelial cell marker used in identifying epithelial tumors such as thymoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 111

choices.text: LAP score
FISH and PCR

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

choices.text: Measurement of erythropoietin levels
Bone marrow biopsy
Genetic testing for JAK2 mutation

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy from a high-altitude village presents to the emergency department with a high fever, weakness, and fatigue. He has been living at high altitudes all his life. His physical examination reveals a flushed face, mild splenomegaly, and no signs of cyanosis. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 17 g/dL, a total leukocyte count of 21,000, with differential showing 25% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, 5% eosinophils, and 40% immature myeloid cells, including myelocytes and metamyelocytes. Given these findings, what should be the next step in the investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Measurement of erythropoietin levels

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario suggests polycythemia, characterized by elevated hemoglobin levels (>16 g/dL). The next step should be to measure erythropoietin levels, which helps distinguish between primary and secondary forms of polycythemia. Polycythemia vera (PCV), a primary form of polycythemia, typically shows low erythropoietin levels due to autonomous production of red blood cells driven by JAK2 mutations. In contrast, secondary forms, often seen in high-altitude residents or those with erythropoietin-secreting tumors, present with elevated erythropoietin levels. Evaluating erythropoietin levels helps guide further testing and management, including differentiating between PCV and other causes of absolute polycythemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow biopsy
A bone marrow biopsy may be considered later but is not the initial step. It is typically used to confirm PCV by showing panmyelosis, particularly increased red cell production, but the first step should be to evaluate erythropoietin levels.

 

Option C. Genetic testing for JAK2 mutation
Testing for JAK2 mutations is crucial for diagnosing PCV, but it should follow erythropoietin level testing. Low erythropoietin levels would prompt JAK2 testing to confirm PCV, whereas high levels would indicate secondary causes, making JAK2 testing less relevant.

 

Option D. Chest X-ray
A chest X-ray would not provide specific information relevant to polycythemia. It might be useful if lung disease was suspected as a secondary cause of polycythemia, but in this context, it is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the evaluation of polycythemia, measuring erythropoietin levels is essential to differentiate primary causes like polycythemia vera, which shows low erythropoietin, from secondary causes with elevated erythropoietin levels. This initial step guides further diagnostic evaluation and management, including the consideration of genetic testing for JAK2 mutations in suspected cases of polycythemia vera.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus
Ebstein Barr virus

questions.text: A patient underwent a renal transplant following which he developed an infection that had owl eye inclusions. What is the likely cause of the finding? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

The presence of owl eye inclusions in a patient with a history of immunosuppression (such as following a renal transplant) is highly suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

 

  • Pathology: CMV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is a common cause of infection in immunocompromised individuals. The virus causes the formation of characteristic intranuclear inclusions that resemble owl's eyes.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with fever, fatigue, and signs of organ-specific involvement, such as pneumonitis, hepatitis, or retinitis, depending on the site of infection.
  • Histopathology: The characteristic finding on histopathology is the presence of large cells with basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of owl's eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Typically causes vesicular lesions and does not produce owl eye inclusions.

 

Option B. Epstein Barr virus: Associated with infectious mononucleosis and various lymphoproliferative disorders, not typically owl eye inclusions.

 

Option D. HIV: Causes immunosuppression but does not produce characteristic owl eye inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl eye inclusions seen in immunocompromised patients, especially post-transplant, are indicative of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

 

Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving.

 

Principles of blood administration:

 

  • All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter.
  • A careful aseptic technique should be practiced at all times.
  • Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased.
  • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient's cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature.
  • No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product.
  • Ringer's lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation.
  • After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient's chart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank: This option is incorrect as the emphasis is on completing the transfusion within 4 hours, not just starting it.

 

Option C. No such time restraint and can be done anytime: This is incorrect, as there is a specific time frame to prevent bacterial proliferation.

 

Option D. It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank: This option is incorrect; the recommended maximum time for completion is 4 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank to minimize the risk of bacterial proliferation and ensure patient safety.

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant Disorders

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by a consistent appearance of affected individuals in every generation, with no sex bias and manifestation in individuals who carry one copy of the mutant allele.
